10

Red Sox sellout streak proves to be numbers game

The Red Sox declare a game sold out even if hundreds of tickets go unsold but others are given away for free, all to keep the streak of sold out home games alive. (Globe)
  • survey What do you think of the sellout streak?
  • pictures How the Red Sox define "sellout"
  • 4/13: As Red Sox sputter early, sellout streak in jeopardy

Commercial food waste to be banned

The proposed rules to ban businesses in Mass. from discarding food waste in the trash beginning in 2014 are to save space in landfills and reduce gas emissions. (Globe)
  • graphic Projected landfill capacity in Mass.
  • video Plant reduces farm waste sent to landfills
  • 4/29: Hamilton, Wenham pioneers in paring waste

Bill Brett's latest Boston party photos

More than 300 guests were at the Boston Harbor Hotel May 2d to support Crossroads for Kids, helping to raise over $350,000 for the nonprofit serving at-risk youth.

Liberty Mutual profited on Kelly's watch

Liberty Mutual says its recovery from near bankruptcy after retired CEO Edmund "Ted" Kelly took over is a reason for Kelly's past $50 million annual pay. (Globe)
  • graphic Liberty Mutual's revenue, net assets since 1992
  • 4/28: Liberty Mutual’s Kelly explains pay  |  Video
  • 4/26: Liberty Mutual profits up 26% for 2012 first quarter

Microsoft plans Boston retail store

West Coast software giant Microsoft Corp. is expanding its East Coast presence with a retail store in The Shops at Prudential Center and a New York research lab. (Globe)
  • Microsoft ranks on list of top places to work

Bland Zakim Bridge leaves us feeling blue

Our famous blue bridge is awash in a dreary glaze of white, from the lanes to the cables to the towers.

A hiring spree at UMass Memorial Medical School in Worcester will add 100 faculty to fill a $400 million biomedical research building set to open this year.

American Repertory Theater’s “Woody Sez” captures Guthrie’s vision as a political agitator and spiritual influence on everyone from Bob Dylan to Wilco.

Zander to lead new youth ensemble

Benjamin Zander, who was fired by the New England Conservatory for hiring a convicted sex offender to film its youth orchestra, will lead a new youth ensemble at the Boston Philharmonic Orchestra.
